Read Actively with Maus

Jul 7, 2021

Through Vladek Spiegelman’s personal experiences during the Holocaust, Art Spiegelman’s graphic novel, Maus (1986), depicts a pivotal time in world history. As the author references real dates, events, people, ideas, and places, various note-taking strategies become useful. Readers may better understand and remember their reading if they record the dates of important events, explore new or significant vocabulary, or mark on a map some of the places that Vladek Spiegelman mentions.

Make a Timeline

Date page Event
1938 32-33 Vladek sees a Nazi flag, sees the swastika for the first time, and hears about pogroms in Germany
1939 44 Vladek and other Polish soldiers begin to fight the Nazis
1940 73 Vladek returns home from a Prisoner of War (P.O.W.) camp
1941 82 A new order states that all Jewish people in Sosnowiec, Poland, must move to a specific quarter
1942 86 A new order states that Nazis will take away all Jewish people over 70 years old
1943 105 The remaining Jewish people in Sosnowiec must go to the Srodula ghetto
1944 157 Vladek arrives at the Auschwitz concentration camp

Explore Key Vocabulary

Terms Related to Jewish Culture
Term page My Definition
synagogue 33 A Jewish congregation, a house of worship and communal center
rabbi 57 Teacher, leader of a Jewish congregation
Torah 57 Jewish scripture
Zionist 83 A person who aligns with Zionism - the international movement to establish and support a Jewish nation or religious community
Terms Related to the Holocaust
Term page My Definition
Holocaust 23 Genocide of 6 million Jewish people and millions of other people during World War II
Hitler 23 Adolf Hitler - Nazi party leader and initiator of World War II
Nazi 49 Member of the German fascist party in control of Germany from 1933 to 1945 under Adolf Hitler
swastika 32 Symbol of anti-Semitism or Nazism
pogrom 33 Organized massacre of people, specifically Jewish people
anti-Semitic 36 Hostile or discriminatory against Jewish people
ghetto 82 A quarter of the city where Nazis force Jewish people to live
Auschwitz 78 Oświęcim, site of a World War II Nazi concentration camp in Poland
Theresienstadt 86 Terezín, site of a World War II Nazi concentration camp/ghetto in the Czech Republic.

Make a Map


References

Spiegelman, A. (1986). Maus. Pantheon Books.
